docs.abstract: Bill Keller Op-Ed column contends Pres Obama's approach to issue of race has consistently been calibrated and cautious; suggests people, both black and white, have typecast him according to their own fears and expectations of a black man in the White House; holds this, in effect, is profiling Obama and questions why many believe it is his job to confront America's racism in a more overt way.
docs.lead_paragraph: Why is it his job to confront America’s racism?

docs.abstract: Some eerie parallels between President Obama's State of the Union speech and some statements by Herbert Hoover, who presided during the early years of the Great Depression.
docs.lead_paragraph: David A. Rosenberg, the chief economist and strategist at Gluskin Sheff, noticed some eerie parallels between President Obama's State of the Union speech and some statements by Herbert Hoover, who presided during the early years of the Great Depression. From Mr. Rosenberg's client note today:

docs.abstract: Democrat Dina Titus defeats incumbent Republican Jon Porter in Nevada Congressional race; control of State Legislature shifts to Democrats; Barack Obama wins state, 55-43 percent; tallies (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama won this swing state, which has seen rapid population growth, demographic shifts and a rapidly deflating real estate market. President Bush won the state in 2004. Dina Titus, a Democratic state senator and a political science professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, beat the incumbent three-term Republican, Jon Porter, in the Third Congressional District, where Democrats have come to outnumber Republicans since the last election.

docs.abstract: Maine Republican Sen Susan Collins wins re-election over challenge by Democratic Rep Tom Allen; Democrats Chellie M Pingree and Michael H Michaud win Congressional races; Barack Obama wins state, 58-40 percent; tallies (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Susan Collins, a Republican, was elected to a third term, easily beating her Democratic challenger, Representative Tom Allen. Ms. Collins portrayed herself as a moderate with a long record of working on bipartisan legislation, an approach that made it difficult for Mr. Allen to link her to an unpopular President Bush.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: SAME-SEX MARRIAGE, CIVIL UNIONS AND DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIPS

docs.abstract: Republican Duncan Hunter Jr wins California Congressional seat held by his father, who is retiring; Democrat Jerry McNerney retains his House seat; outcome is unclear in Congressional race between Democrat Charlie Brown and Republican Tom McClintock; voters pass same-sex marriage ban; Barack Obama wins state, 61-37 percent; tallies (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over a ballot measure to ban gay marriage overshadowed other contests, including the presidential race and battles for a handful of Congressional districts. The same-sex marriage ban passed with more than 52 percent of the vote.
docs.snippet: The debate over a ballot measure to ban gay marriage overshadowed other contests, including the presidential race and battles for a handful of Congressional districts.     The same-sex marriage ban passed with more than 52 percent of the vote....

headline.main: Jon Huntsman Is in Running to Be Ambassador to Russia
headline.print_headline: Republican Who Served Obama in Beijing Is in the Running to Be Moscow Envoy

docs.lead_paragraph: Sending Mr. Huntsman to Moscow would remove him as a primary challenger to Utah’s 82-year-old Republican senator, Orrin Hatch.

headline.main: Obama Lets Bad Puns Fly at Turkey Pardoning Tinged With Sadness

docs.lead_paragraph: “I know there are some bad ones in here, but this is the last time I’m doing this, so we’re not leaving any room for leftovers,” he said to some laughter.

docs.abstract: Oregon Senate race between incumbent Republican Gordon H Smith and Democratic challenger Jeff Merkley remains undecided; Barack Obama wins state, 56-42 percent; tallies (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Gordon H. Smith, a two-term Republican, was in a nip-and-tuck race with Jeff Merkley, a Democrat who is the speaker of Oregon's state house. With 79 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Smith had fallen behind Mr. Merkley by about 9,700 votes. Mr. Merkley has been counting on a statewide surge in voter registration among Democrats spurred by the campaign of Senator Barack Obama.
